segments.text: North Korea, China, and Cuba was greatly enhanced by the demonstration of total freedom that those people demonstrated throughout the world.
And I don't think it's going to be long until North Korea and China and Cuba, the Communist parties, will lose power.
Why do you feel that the anti-war activists were against the war?
Well, I say, I don't think they were against the war.
They were against everything.
There was what was called a Chicago Five.
I don't remember all of them.
Jerry Rubin was one of the major ones.
But they were a group of hippies that really

was the leadership in all the drug experimentation and so forth and there was a professor who's still out at the university of california the lsd king i forget yeah leary timothy o'leary although i think he was at the school in boston at that time he subsequently moved to california they were a group of people that was against everything and the war just happened to be there and if it hadn't been a war
they would have been against something.
Now, I attended some congressional hearings while these people were being questioned.
And they're absolutely the scum of the earth.
You would not believe how they were.
And like I say, they were against everything.
Now, there were some people there who truly were against
They thought the United States was wrong.
And these people I have no problem with.
They have a right to believe one way or the other.
But my judgment is that was probably 10 or 15%.
The rest of them were professional antagonists.
They were against everything.
And this was just a good cause.
They were not employed.
I don't know how they supported themselves.
There certainly was no significant economic support base for these people.
A lot of the rock music was getting to be big, big things.
And they were having big, well, I think Woodstock was one of them.
But this is where they gathered their people from.
They were able to get a group of people.
And college students always have been and always will be very easy to get emotionally involved in things.
Fortunately, we've always managed to get this emotional energy involved in a positive direction.
And as a result of that, much good has been done by the youth of this country over the years.
But when you get the wrong leaders involved like they did at that period of time, they can be a tremendous force.
Large numbers of people, rather than being drafted, went to Canada and other places.
But Canada was the primary place that
avoid the draft.

But it was just a situation where we had leadership that could take advantage of the emotion of the youth that were simply leading them in the anti-war direction because there just happened to be a war.
How'd you feel about soldiers that came back and started
becoming involved with the anti-war movement?
Well, there again, particularly, you know, there are young men we're talking about here.
Well, first of all, some of them truly believed that what we were doing was wrong.
And their experience may very well have been a very bad experience.
You know, I told you to begin with.
This sort of thing is a very subjective thing.
Now, nothing that I was involved with while I was in Vietnam was bad.
There were no atrocities where my unit was involved with.
We did not treat the people badly.
I had absolutely no reason whatsoever
to come back here and not feel pride in having done a good job and having done what our government wanted us to do.

Now, if I had been in an outfit like was involved in some of these massacres, like Lieutenant Kelly, I'm sure you've read about this, but probably don't know the full extent of it, then yeah, I probably could have been
coaxed into demonstrating against the United States because that was bad.
And so anyone that was involved in bad situations was going to be very likely subject to being recruited into the anti-war.
I read General Schwarzkopf's.
novel, not novel, autobiography.
I don't know whether you read it or not.
But he was a battalion commander about the same time that I was.
And he talked in not very flowery terms about the condition of the battalion that he was in.
It was bad.
And he said so.
It had bad leaders.
And the people
probably were involved in some bad things.
So I can understand how a young private who spent a year in a situation like that would have come back very demoralized.
And I don't mean that as a slap at the Army, OK?
Because the Army had to mobilize from a relatively small force with worldwide responsibilities.
into a very large force who still had its worldwide primarily European responsibilities and then still had to provide a large force for Vietnam.
As a result of that, I believe Gerald Schwarzkopf indicated that he only had two or three NCOs in his entire battalion that had combat experience.
His officers
were were very inexperienced.
Now you take the battalion I was in now.
We had staff NCOs, many of which had Korean experience.
I had been to Korea.
I guess I was the only officer that had Korean experience.
I can't recall.
Yeah, I'm sure I was.
But
My company commanders, platoon commanders and so forth, were top quality.
As a result of that, we didn't have disciplinary problems.
We did not have problems with dope, which General Schwarzkopf wrote about, which many other people have talked to me about.
We didn't have all those problems.
And as a result,
Not only was my experience a positive one, but the experience of the troopers were positive.
So I would be shocked if any of them were involved at our war movement.
But the other young people who had lesser quality experiences, yeah.
You see, I left there and went to Army staff in the Pentagon.
My contemporaries there were Army officers.
And the experiences that they shared with me were quite similar to what General Schwarzkopf said about his unit.
And when I would relate my experiences to them, they couldn't believe it.
They would tell me about the so-called fragging that used to go on.
We didn't have any problems like that.
We talk about the discipline where our lack of discipline, where young soldiers would refuse orders.
We didn't have that sort of stuff.
And like I say, one of the reasons that the Army had this problem is they had to expand so quickly
They had to take so many draftees that their training base did not allow them to train these people properly.
They were not able to provide enough experienced officers and non-commissioned officers to the units in Vietnam.
And as a result, it was often terrible, absolutely terrible.
Like I said, fortunately, we didn't
I'll bet you that half of the staff NCOs in my battalion were on their second tour in Vietnam and many of them on their third tour.
So they knew what was going on and so forth.
But a lot of that has to do with leadership from the top.
Now, when I say the top,
Really, I think the last level of command that has a direct influence on the soldier or Marine is the battalion commander.
The regimental brigade or division commander, he'll have some influence over the battalion commander, but first of all, never is going to get around the troopers.
I think that because we had fewer commitments worldwide than the Army did, we were able to have a higher quality battalion commander.
Now, just as an example, I recall I had sent a patrol one day out through this village and they had to
They were to go out about 10 or 12 kilometers and come back.
And this was a platoon-sized patrol, about 40 men.
As they were going through this village, for some unknown reason, they passed this Buddhist temple.
And they started breaking the cups and so forth, cups and saucers that were on the outside of this temple.
The lieutenant who was in command of the platoon didn't stop him.
Well, the word got back to me as to what happened.
And I made him buy plates and saucers to replace.
It cost him $250 to replace them.
And so the word gets out, not only can you not kill innocent people the way
They were in some places.
You can't even destroy their property, because if you do, this guy's going to make you pay for it.
And when you control troops, when they do what you want them to and do not do the wrong thing, well, first of all, you never have any massacres.
You don't kill innocent women and children.
It's just a matter of respect for being in one's country and so forth.
And I just don't think many Army units had experiences like that.
And I say this because, like I say, I was stationed with them after I left, and they just couldn't believe that
that we operate this way and they operate it in a totally different manner.
What types of training did you have to go through in order to work in civil disturbances?
Well, there wasn't any, you mean for me personally, there was nothing.
You know, they just, I had orders to go to headquarters Marine Corps and I don't even remember now what branch I was scheduled to go to.
And the day I got there, they said, no, you're not going there.
You're going to go and be on the Army staff.
I said, why me?
Well, they give me this cock and bull story about all my qualifications.
And I finally told them, I said, this is a bunch of BS.
Why am I going over there?
They said, they want someone right now, and you're the first one coming in.
So we got through all this qualification bit.
And I was just an able body to go over there
and represent the Marine Corps.

Of course, by the same token, at this point I had 20 years in the Marine Corps, so I was completely familiar with all of our organization capabilities and so forth, and I had served in many, many positions, so I was able to help in the planning that we had to do.
Now, as far as

the people that we utilized in civil disturbances, we did put them through riot control training and lots of other things because the idea when you're involved in this sort of thing is to accomplish your mission without using any more force than was absolutely necessary.
Also, we were involved in the training, testing, and monitoring of all your National Guard and Reserve units at the time.
And that's what took up most of our efforts, was trying to see that they were ready to do it.
See, there's a law in the United States called
Posse Comitatus Act, which says, in effect, that regular forces cannot be used to enforce the law, except when the governor of a state tells the president, I need help.
Now, the basis of that is good.
It's to keep the armed forces from being used in any way which could
maybe give them an insight as to how to take over the government?
Now, the irony of it is that the Marine Corps is exempted from that act.
So actually, Marines can be used in a law enforcement mode, whereas the Army cannot.
But fortunately, the requirement was on the wane.
by the time I got there.
We thought it was going to get worse, but actually we had already seen the worst part of it by the time I got to Washington.
Did your training change or how did it change over the three years that you worked in civil disturbances?
The training that soldiers went through to work?
Yes, it did.
The emphasis was on riot control.
And it was how to move various formations that would be used to move a group of people out of an area.
A wedge, for instance.
A wedge is the way you split a piece of wood.
Well, that's the way you break up a group of rioters or demonstrators, is you split them into more
usable, not usable, but controllable size groups.
The use of tear gas and other things, the billy club, non-deadly force was stressed.
But almost everything else that a soldier or a Marine does in his regular training is also quite usable in civil disturbances.
But one of the basic mistakes and the most, well, I'm looking for a word.
I can't find it.
But on Kent State, I don't know whether you've read anything on that or not.
Now, this was National Guard.
This was not Army.
This was National Guard.
Forces were used there.
The truth of the matter is they panicked.
And they started shooting live ammunition at demonstrators.
That should never happen.

But it goes back to the basic problem that I discussed earlier, and that is the fact that the Army and its extension as the National Guard was poorly, poorly trained, poorly organized, poorly led to the point of almost being criminally
You have to realize, though, how a National Guard works.
And I want to be quick to say the National Guard today is 20 times better than it was then.
And each state is different.
But I don't think there was a single state that could say theirs was good then or that was properly led.
It was politically led.
These people, a large percentage of the people and all of the leadership were politically appointed.

For instance, it wouldn't be unusual at all to find the adjutant general, who is the commander of the state's National Guard, to have been a captain in the Guard one day, and the right governor takes over, and the next day he's a major general in the Guard.
Well, just because you pin stars on his shoulder doesn't make him any more qualified today than he was yesterday when he had captain's bars on his shoulder.
Quite the contrary, he probably was a pure politician or he wouldn't have had that kind of pull with the government.
The National Guard then, and they were the first line of defense, was terrible.
There's no other way to state it.
They were terrible.
They were ill-equipped, ill-trained, ill-organized, and it was just a bad scene.
And in Kent State, there were several people killed.
And it was demonstrated to a lesser degree numerous times throughout.
The National Guard has improved vastly.
Did your views on Vietnam change when you were there the first time in 67 to when you participated in the evacuation in 75?
No.
I believe that we were there.
Now, when I say we, I was there as a Marine.
Now, why we as a nation was there, that's another matter.
And you need to keep that in perspective.
A professional military man is there and doing something because his commander in chief told him to.
And he doesn't have to agree totally with his commander in chief.
He just has to do what he's told.
I believe that our reason for going there was honorable.
I believe that there were
truly political mistakes that were made.
There were military mistakes that were made.
But anyone who waits until he finds a perfect situation before he is involved will never be involved in anything.
I believe we were right being there.
I believe we did a professional job.
I believe that the decisions to restrict military activity was a political decision.
I believe those decisions should be political.
And when the political decision is made by the commander in chief,
and he says, this is what we're going to do, then it is the job of the military to do it.
And it should always be that way.
The military should never, ever, ever be the controlling factor.
They should never, ever, ever make political decisions.
They should always be consulted and asked for advice, but they should never, ever
make political decisions.
That's how you get a Russia.
That's how you get several other communist countries.
No, to answer your question, my view did not change.
I went back there in 1975 under orders of the command in chief to evacuate those people.
We did a good job.
I would not do it differently.
I felt proud the first time I left there.
I felt proud the second time I left there.
We did what we were told to do with the absolute minimum loss of life.
And when you can walk away saying we've done the job and we have lost the absolute minimum number of people, then you have no reason to be anything other than proud.
Describe your role in the evacuation of Saigon and Laos.
Well, my role in Laos was strictly one of being a reserve battalion.
I was not called upon.
We stayed aboard the aircraft carrier ready to go, but we were not needed.
My role in the evacuation of Saigon was that I was to go in
and occupy the location where the CIA had operated out of.
Another battalion was to go into the embassy, and a third battalion was to be the reserve.
We were getting ready to launch.
I already had one company that was airborne.
I was in the helicopter myself and was getting ready to lift off.
And the pilot said, hey, the captain wants to see you.
We've been told to stand down.
Well, the bottom line was the CIA area, which was called Air America, that was their cover, had been lost to the North Vietnamese.
And so the choice had to be made, either we're going to not
use that as an evacuation point, or I was going to have to go in there and retake it.
In other words, I was going to have to make an assault on the plane.
Well, the decision was made that we would not do that, and it was a good decision.
I don't take exception to that.
So there again, I sat as the reserve battalion aboard the aircraft carrier Hancock

waiting to go in if needed and i did not go in so my participation was strictly one of handling the evacuees as they come back to the ship that i was on now i had troops on two other ships and i did have one platoon

which was airborne the entire time as just a ready reserve that could go in in the event a helicopter went down or something, that they could go in and secure the site until whatever additional evacuation was necessary.
But we took care of them.
people as they came back and that was the full extent of it.
So I was just a reserve battalion in both of those operations.
Describe your feelings about the evacuation and if it was a defeat for the Marine Corps.
Oh, definitely not a defeat.
We come out of there under orders.
And I might add that if you looked at that operation, if you studied that operation, I would say that there was one mistake made.
And that was one of a pilot who had been, again,
an aircraft that was on standby in the event another aircraft went down.
That crew had been airborne over 12 hours on that particular day.
And fortunately, we had not lost any other aircraft.
Not another aircraft had gone down.
So he had been simply a standby aircraft for 12 hours.
He had landed two or three times to refuel.
He'd come back out to the ship to land and refuel.
But other than that, he'd been airborne.
And, oh, I guess it was an hour after dark.
I don't remember when the operation had, in fact, been completed.
He was coming back in to our carrier to land.
And he simply drove that helicopter into the city.
And the pilots have a term for this.
They understood what happened.
He was fixed on the lights of the carrier.
And after a while, your eyes fool you is what he came out to do.
He truly thought he was landing on the aircraft carrier, and he drove it into the water about 400 yards off him.
And even though that helicopter was supposed to float, it went down like a sea anchor, and all four men were killed.
Now that was the...
